body: `PrimitiveName` seems like the blocker to an abstract `TypeName` class.

issue.body:
Anyone know a good way to test this without writing a novel of mocking? I filed https://github.com/google/compile-testing/issues/65 which seems like it would be a good approach.

Closes #228.

body:
Why is `PrimitiveName` a blocker?
Actually, I'm looking here http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33055732/compare-javapoet-parameterspec-type-with-java-8-annotatedtype for an `AnnotatedTypeName`-related answer. May be, a solution to this issue will pop up.
@sormuras There used to be a `PrimitiveName` that was an `enum` (see PR #138); it was in JavaWriter though, and has been removed in JavaPoet.
It's got to be composition, not inheritance.
Otherwise `String` and `@Nullable String` need to be equal or not, and either way we're hosed.
Composition like above w/o the `extends TypeName`?

Ja, another keen way to get an _ATN_ handle.

One more thought concering inheritance - what's the difference here in respect to equality and `List` and `List<String>`? They're _not_ equal in terms of JavaPoet-model classes, one is a `ClassName` and one is a `ParameterizedTypeName`, right?

Using `$T` for all kind of types, speaks for itself.

Ah - maybe, you didn't see the composition in the code snippet above. It's actually both: extending `TypeName` for the model integration (`$T` et al) and holding a reference to an underlying `TypeName`. Just like `ParameterizedTypeName` does.

body: Removed the static getters - as they use Java 8 `TypeMirror` interface. It doesn't extends `javax.lang.model.AnnotatedConstruct` in 7 and lower.
